Title: Sending Email Correctly in .NET
Description:
Get 30% off everything on Dometrain: https://dometrain.com/courses/?ref=nick-chapsas&promo=youtube&coupon_code=SUMMER30
Subscribe to my weekly newsletter: https://nickchapsas.com

Hello, everybody. I'm Nick, and in this video, Dylan Beattie will show you to properly and correctly send emails in .NET. Sending emails is a fundamental feature of almost every application and understanding how to do it properly is one of the most important things you can do to get an edge over other developers.

Subscribe to Dylan Beattie: https://www.youtube.com/dylanbeattie

Title: Why You Should Add Indexes to Foreign Key Refs in PostgreSQL
Description:
Overview

When building a data model for PostgreSQL, you're more than likely to have foreign keys to define relationships between tables. When you have those foreign keys, one quick way to optimize your queries and allow them to be significantly faster is to index on those foreign key references.

Title: Qutting GitHub
Description:
I’ve had this post sitting in my drafts since April. I decided to finish it in light of the news that GitHub is no longer independent inside Microsoft and going full-tilt into AI slop.
I’ve decided to migrate all of my personal projects1 off GitHub— come join me.
Going forward, my public work will be on https://codeberg.org/jpt/
Read on if you’d like to understand why, or you can skip to Where To? if you’d like to make a similar move.

Title: RAG-Shot Learning - Joseph Cooper
Description: RAG-enhanced few-shot learning improves LLM performance by retrieving relevant labeled examples during inference, eliminating the need for fine-tuning while achieving comparable results.

Title: How Large Language Models Parse Content
Description: An insightful exploration into how Large Language Models parse and understand content, highlighting the importance of structure, verifiable claims, and semantic density in AI comprehension.

Title: Optimising for trust
Description:
TDD, BDD, DDD, Agile, SAFe, Scrum, Kanban, XP… there’s a lot of ways to skin a cat write code in a professional environment.
I take pride in being a person who is a non-ideologue when it comes to my code. There are many good ways of working, and they are all context-dependent.
You can’t apply the same things that worked when you were a two-person startup operating out of the proverbial garage and expect them to work once your hypothetical unicorn has reached a thousand-plus developers. Even within the same organisation, processes that work for one team can be catastrophic when applied to their neighbouring team.

Title: Big Tech Employee Giving Program Tier List
